segment.source: Validating Universal Windows drivers
segment.target: Validating Universal Windows drivers

segment.source: You can use the ApiValidator.exe tool to verify that the APIs that your driver calls are valid for a Universal Windows driver.
segment.target: You can use the ApiValidator.exe tool to verify that the APIs that your driver calls are valid for a Universal Windows driver.

segment.source: The tool returns an error if your driver calls an API that is outside the set of valid APIs for Universal Windows drivers.
segment.target: The tool returns an error if your driver calls an API that is outside the set of valid APIs for Universal Windows drivers.

segment.source: This tool is part of the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) for Windows 10.
segment.target: This tool is part of the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) for Windows 10.

segment.source: Running ApiValidator in Visual Studio
segment.target: Running ApiValidator in Visual Studio

segment.source: If the Target Platform property of your driver project is set to Universal, Visual Studio runs ApiValidator automatically as a post-build step.
segment.target: If the Target Platform property of your driver project is set to Universal, Visual Studio runs ApiValidator automatically as a post-build step.

segment.source: To view all the messages displayed by ApiValidator, navigate to Tools > Options > Projects and Solutions > Build and Run, and set MSBuild project build output verbosity to Detailed.
segment.target: To view all the messages displayed by ApiValidator, navigate to Tools > Options > Projects and Solutions > Build and Run, and set MSBuild project build output verbosity to Detailed.

segment.source: When building from the command line, add the switch /v:detailed or /v:diag to your build command to increase the verbosity.
segment.target: When building from the command line, add the switch /v:detailed or /v:diag to your build command to increase the verbosity.

segment.source: For the umdf2\_fx2 driver sample, API validation errors look this:
segment.target: For the umdf2\_fx2 driver sample, API validation errors look this:

segment.source: Fixing validation errors
segment.target: Fixing validation errors

segment.source: If you switched a legacy desktop driver to universal, verify that you are including the correct libraries.
segment.target: If you switched a legacy desktop driver to universal, verify that you are including the correct libraries.

segment.source: Right click the project and choose properties.
segment.target: Right click the project and choose properties.

segment.source: Navigate to Linker->Input.
segment.target: Navigate to Linker->Input.

segment.source: The Additional Dependencies should contain:
segment.target: The Additional Dependencies should contain:

segment.source: Remove or replace the non-universal API calls one at a time and rerun the tool until there are no errors.
segment.target: Remove or replace the non-universal API calls one at a time and rerun the tool until there are no errors.

segment.source: Running ApiValidator from the Command Prompt
segment.target: Running ApiValidator from the Command Prompt

segment.source: You can also run Apivalidator.exe from the command prompt.
segment.target: You can also run Apivalidator.exe from the command prompt.

segment.source: In your WDK installation, navigate to C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\<arch>.
segment.target: In your WDK installation, navigate to C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\<arch>.

segment.source: Use the following syntax:
segment.target: Use the following syntax:

source.pc: <path to XML files containing supported APIs for universal drivers>

target.pc: <path to XML files containing supported APIs for universal drivers>

segment.source: For example, to verify the APIs called by the Activity sample in the WDK, first build the sample in Visual Studio.
segment.target: For example, to verify the APIs called by the Activity sample in the WDK, first build the sample in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Then open a command prompt and navigate to the directory containing the tool, for example C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x64.
segment.target: Then open a command prompt and navigate to the directory containing the tool, for example C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x64.

segment.source: Enter the following command:
segment.target: Enter the following command:

segment.source: apivalidator.exe -DriverPackagePath:"C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\src\\usb\\umdf2\_fx2\\Debug\\\\" -SupportedApiXmlFiles:"c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\build\\universalDDIs\\x64\\UniversalDDIs.xml"
segment.target: apivalidator.exe -DriverPackagePath:"C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\src\\usb\\umdf2\_fx2\\Debug\\\\" -SupportedApiXmlFiles:"c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\build\\universalDDIs\\x64\\UniversalDDIs.xml"

segment.source: The command produces the following output:
segment.target: The command produces the following output:

segment.source: The XML files that enumerate the valid APIs for Universal Windows drivers are located in C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\build\\universalDDIs\\<arch>.
segment.target: The XML files that enumerate the valid APIs for Universal Windows drivers are located in C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\10\\build\\universalDDIs\\<arch>.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.target: If ApiValidator.exe outputs an incorrect format error such as the following:

segment.target: Use this workaround:

segment.source: Open Project properties, navigate to General, and rename Output Directory to the following:
segment.target: Open Project properties, navigate to General, and rename Output Directory to the following:

segment.source: Rebuild the solution.
segment.target: Rebuild the solution.
